title: Canadian committee to probe â€˜explosiveâ€™ Indian violence allegations
description: A parliamentary committee will probe new allegations of Indian foreign interference in Canada that led to the expulsion of diplomats.
article:
A parliamentary committee will probe  new allegations of Indian foreign interference in Canada  that led to the expulsion of diplomats by both countries in tat-for-tat-moves.

At an emergency meeting on Friday, MPs on the standing committee on public safety and national security agreed to undertake a study concerning the â€œelectoral interference and violent criminal activities carried out by agents the Government of India.â€

This came after new revelations from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, which said on Monday that it has significant information on criminal activity allegedly orchestrated by  agents of the Indian government. 

The evidence points to â€œviolent extremismâ€ in both countries, links tying Indian government agents to homicides and violent acts, use of organized crime targeting the South Asian community in Canada, and interference in democratic processes,  according to the RCMP. 

NDP MP Alistair MacGregor moved the motion to start the probe, which was agreed after amendments in a vote by all members on the committee.

â€œFor the RCMP, indeed, for any police force that is conducting an active investigation to come out with such explosive revelations, I think underscores just how serious this is,â€ MacGregor said on Friday.

As part of this study, it was agreed that at least six meetings will be held.

The committee will invite senior officials like Foreign Minister Melanie Joly, Public Safety Minister Dominic LeBlanc, RCMP Commissioner Mike Duheme, National Security and Intelligence Advisor Nathalie Drouin.

The Conservatives said they would also like to hear from incoming CSIS director Daniel Rogers, as well as Shawn Tupper, the deputy minister of Public Safety Canada and the deputy minister of Global Affairs Canada, David Morrison.

Other witnesses include experts from Canadaâ€™s South Asian community, Brampton Mayor Patrick Brown, any former leadership candidates of the 2022 Conservative Party leadership race and national security subject matter experts.

An additional category of witnesses will also testify on the impact of the disinformation campaign by India, the committee agreed.

Relations between India and Canada have soured since 2023 when Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said Canadian intelligence agencies had credible evidence linking agents of the Indian government to the assassination of Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey, B.C.

India has long denied any involvement in Nijjarâ€™s killing andÂ accused Trudeau on Monday of pursuing a â€œpolitical agenda.â€

Global News has learned agents working out of Indiaâ€™s high commission in Ottawa and consulates in Vancouver and Toronto were behind dozens of violent crimes across Canada that targeted opponents of the Narendra Modi government.

According to senior sources familiar with the matter, supporters of the  Khalistan  movement, which seeks independence for Indiaâ€™s Sikh-majority Punjab region, as well as rivals of the Modi government, were targeted.

NDPâ€™s MacGregor also put forward a second motion on Friday calling on all federal party leaders to apply for the â€œappropriate security clearance level in the next 30 days in order to review classified information and take necessary actions to protect Canadians.â€

Trudeau suggested Wednesday that Canadian intelligence agencies have information that  multiple Conservative politicians are â€œengaged or at riskâ€  from foreign interferenceÂ schemes.

Trudeau noted that list of names include Liberal politicians as well as those from â€œother parties,â€ without expanding on what the parliamentarians were suspected of doing.

The second motion got pushback from Conservative MPs on Friday who instead pressed for the release of names of all parliamentarians who are alleged to have interfered with and knowingly colluded with foreign powers.

â€œThese names have to have to come out â€¦ and thereâ€™s only one person who can do that, and thatâ€™s the prime minister of Canada,â€ said Conservative MP Melissa Lantsman.

â€œCanadians deserve to know which members of Parliament in which party, no matter what, are colluding with foreign governments, wittingly or unwittingly.â€

Green Party Leader Elizabeth May argued that releasing such names would â€œbreak the lawâ€ and could place Canadian intelligence assets â€œat risk.â€

Making names public poses â€œa threat to Canadian security and can actually jeopardize lives,â€ May said.

MacGregor proposed that any release of names should ensure that it protects national security and those who gathered the intelligence.

The committee will reconvene next week on Tuesday.

title: How the Hunterâ€™s supermoon looked in photos from around the world
description: This weekâ€™s full moon was the Hunterâ€™s supermoon, a name given to the full moon in October â€“ the full moon that occurs just after the autumnal Harvest Moon.
article:
Skygazers across the world were in for a treat this week, as the seasonâ€™s biggest and brightest moon appeared in the night sky â€” the Hunterâ€™s  supermoon .

This weekâ€™s full moon was the Hunterâ€™s Moon, a name given to the full moon in October â€“ the full moon that occurs just after the autumnal harvest. While it peaked just before 7:30 a.m. eastern on Thursday, the lunar phenomenon has been visible over several recent evenings.

According to NASA, the Hunterâ€™s supermoon was seen from Tuesday evening through Friday morning. Here are some of the photos captured from around the world.

This was the third of four supermoons this year and also the brightest, albeit by a tiny margin.

According to the Farmerâ€™s Almanac, this signifies a time of year when leaves have started falling off of trees, making it easier for hunters to spot animals.

A supermoon occurs when the distance between the Earth and the moon is at its lowest point, making the moon appear bigger and brighter than usual.

The next supermoon, the last one of the year, is set to occur on Nov. 15.

title: Millennials, could it be perimenopause? Managing the overlooked life stage
description: Many millennials may unknowingly be experiencing the early signs of perimenopause, a transitional phase to menopause that can start in their late 30s.
article:
Waking up drenched in sweat, having irregular periods and forgetting your friendâ€™s name mid-conversation â€” sound familiar? For many  millennials , these arenâ€™t just signs of a hectic life, but the early symptoms of  perimenopause .

Perimenopause, the transition leading up to menopause, can start as early as the late 30s and last up to 10 years. Yet many people remain unaware theyâ€™re experiencing the symptoms, often attributing them to stress, a busy lifestyle or simply aging.

Millennials, born between 1981 and 1996, may not think theyâ€™re old enough for menopause symptoms, but many are already at an age where early signs of perimenopause can appear.

â€œI call it â€˜millenialpause,'â€ said Dr. Judith Joseph, a medical doctor and board-certified psychiatrist based in New York City, speaking to Global News ahead of World Menopause Day taking place on Friday.

Joseph, who is a millennial herself, explained this generation has much more information at their fingertips about perimenopause and menopause than those before them, leading to help destigmatize the topic and fostering open conversations.

â€œWe are the age of information, so we want to learn about things. We donâ€™t trust people to rescue us,â€ she said. â€œThatâ€™s why I think weâ€™re set up for a better outcome than earlier generations because we just have so much information and we have a culture of curiosity.â€

Although she believes millennials will be more open to discussing the symptoms and impacts of perimenopause, Joseph still sees it as a largely underdiagnosed stage of life.

Menopause is officially diagnosed after a person has gone a full year without a period, usually occurring around the average age of 51, according to the  Menopause Foundation of Canada . Yet, the journey to that milestone â€” referred to as perimenopause â€” brings unexpected emotional and physical challenges that many people may not anticipate.

During this phase, estrogen levels begin to drop, ovulation begins to wind down and menstrual periods become irregular, the Menopause Foundation of Canada stated.

And itâ€™s different than the hormonal changes people feel during their periods, Joseph said.

â€œYouâ€™re going to experience hormonal fluctuations of estrogen and progesterone that are way more intense and way more wide and unpredictable compared to, letâ€™s say, your menstrual period,â€ she explained.

â€œItâ€™s different because leading up to that point where you have your final period and youâ€™re no longer ovulating, those fluctuations are much more intense and they can lead to the symptoms of perimenopause.â€

Tracy Gomes, 54, had always experienced irregular and heavy periods. In her 40s, when the bleeding worsened, the Toronto resident consulted her doctor, who told her she had amenia caused by iron deficiency from excessive blood loss.

But she and her doctor did not know what was causing the heavy blood loss.

â€œI thought it was fibroids and thatâ€™s what I was going back and forth to my doctor about. So I had ultrasounds and all of these tests to see what it was, and I also saw an oncologist for a while,â€ she told Global News.

However, the heavy periods persisted. It wasnâ€™t until Gomes reached her 50s and entered menopause that she realized her previous symptoms, including the heavy bleeding, had been clear signs of perimenopause.

â€œI went to the Menopause Foundation of Canada website and they had a page on symptoms of menopause and symptoms of perimenopause,â€ she said, adding that once she read that heavy periods were a symptom she realized thatâ€™s what she was experiencing.

She was happy she finally found her answer but still upset that her doctor and all the specialists were never able to identify the underlying cause of her symptoms earlier.

This is not uncommon, Joseph explained, as many doctors may be unfamiliar with perimenopause and often attribute the symptoms to other conditions, such as burnout, depression or autoimmune diseases.

â€œWhen I was in medical school, I didnâ€™t knowâ€¦. I thought about menopause as happening when youâ€™re 50. No one told us about perimenopause. This is a relatively new thing for so many health-care professionals,â€ she said.

 Symptoms of perimenopause  can vary but often include:

Itâ€™s important to keep track of these symptoms and discuss them with your health-care provider, Joseph advised, to avoid being misdiagnosed and placed on unnecessary medication.

Several factors can cause some women to show signs of perimenopause earlier than others, Joseph explained.

These factors may include genetics, lifestyle choices such as smoking, diet and exercise, as well as certain medical conditions or treatments, like autoimmune diseases.

Race and ethnicity can also play a role.

â€œDepending on race and background and genetics, Black women and Indigenous women tend to go through perimenopause and menopause earlier, longer and with more severe symptoms,â€ Joseph said.

Healthy eating, getting enough sleep, regular exercise â€” such as strength training, limiting alcohol and avoiding smoking are crucial not only for preventing perimenopausal symptoms but also for relieving discomfort, Joseph said.

â€œNow I really limit alcohol, Iâ€™m eating tons of protein and in terms of working out, Iâ€™m lifting weights,â€ she said.

â€œWhen youâ€™re eating foods that are not processed or sugary, that decreases inflammation in your body. And decreasing inflammation helps with joint pain, it helps with brain fog, it helps with sleep. These lifestyle hacks are really important.â€

She also mentioned that other, more natural, effective methods for managing symptoms include meditation and cognitive behavioural therapy.

There are also hormonal specialists to consult with about whether medication could be a good fit for you, Joseph said.

This includes hormone therapy using estrogen or estrogen and progestins to level out hormones and selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs),  according to Johns Hopkins Medicine .

â€œIt depends because when you see a hormone specialist, they may say hormone replacement therapy or birth control pills,â€ Joseph said, adding that because of all the different treatment options, itâ€™s important to have someone know you and understand your unique biochemistry so they can provide the best treatment.

title: What we know about Ryan Wedding, Canadian Olympian and accused drug lord
description: Ryan Wedding has caught the worldâ€™s attention after the FBI alleged he was the head of a cocaine ring and had been ordering hits in his home country of Canada.
article:
Up until Thursday, some people may have heard Ryan Weddingâ€™s name but most were probably unaware of his existence.

The Canadian Olympian  caught the worldâ€™s attention  when the FBI alleged that he was the head of a cocaine ring and had been ordering hits in his home country from afar.

In the indictments, it was alleged that the cocaine ring he was involved in was moving 60 tonnes of cocaine per year.

The United States Department of Justice (DOJ) announced charges against 16 people on Thursday, including 10 Canadians in connection to a case it had dubbed Project Slalom.

Most have been arrested across North America, aside from Wedding and one other Canadian man.

Here is what we know so far about Wedding:

While Wedding was born in Thunder Bay, Ont., he was a resident of Â Coquitlam, B.C., when he suited up for his country at the Salt Lake City Games in 2002.

He competed in the Parallel Giant Slalom, finishing in 24 place, well behind the leaders.

In a release Thursday, the DOJ said the 43-year-old had been arrested in 2010 in California as part of a drug bust.

They did not say how long he served in connection with that case but they believe he resumed trafficking after he was released and had been protected by the Sinaloa Cartel in Mexico, which was formerly run by Juan (El Chapo) Guzman.

Back in 2015,  RCMP held a news conference  in Halifax announcing that they had charged 15 people. including Wedding. after a two-year drug trafficking investigation.

At the time, they said that Operation Harrington had covered cocaine that was being imported into Canada from countries including Brazil, Colombia, Guyana and the United States.

They said police had seized more than 200 kilograms of cocaine, as well as, weapons and vehicles as a a result of the operation.

They also issued a warrant for the arrest of Wedding, who was said to be from Montreal at the time, on two counts of conspiracy to import cocaine, two counts of conspiracy to traffic cocaine, one count of trafficking in cocaine.

On Thursday, RCMP Chief Superintendent Chris Leather told reporters in Los Angeles that those charges â€œare unresolved.â€

On Thursday, American officials alleged that Wedding was the lead defendant, as they announced charges against 16 people.

The former Canadian Olympian was said to be heading up a cocaine ring for the past 13 years which was said to be a billion-dollar enterprise. The group was moving 60 tonnes of cocaine a year through Mexico and into Southern California before it was distributed into Canada and throughout the U.S.

Wedding and another Canadian, Andrew Clark, were also said to have ordered several hits in Ontario, one of which resulted in the deaths of a couple from Caledon. Police said the two victims were innocent and it was a case of mistaken identity.

The DOJ said he currently resides in Mexico, where his known aliases include â€œEl Jefe,â€ â€œGiantâ€ and â€œPublic Enemy.â€

While Clark, who is known as â€˜The Dictatorâ€™ in Mexico, has been arrested in that country, Wedding remains on the run.

The FBI has offered a US$50,000 reward for information leading to his arrest and extradition to the United States.

title: Liam Payneâ€™s death: One Direction members left â€˜beyond devastatedâ€™
description: One Direction member Liam Payne died in Buenos Aires, Argentina after a fall from a third-floor hotel balcony. He was 31.
article:
Liam Payne â€˜s former  One Direction  bandmates have released joint and individual statements saying they are â€œcompletely devastatedâ€ by the singerâ€™s untimely death on Wednesday.

Payne, 31, died in Buenos Aires, Argentina after he  fell from a third-floor hotel balcony . AnÂ autopsy reportÂ released Thursday revealed Payne died of multiple serious injuries and â€œ internal and external bleeding â€ as a result of the balcony fall.

The surviving One Direction bandmates â€”  Harry Styles ,  Louis Tomlinson ,  Niall Horan  and  Zayn Malik  â€” first published a joint statement to social media late Thursday afternoon.

â€œWeâ€™re completely devastated by the news of Liamâ€™s passing,â€ the  band wrote on Instagram . â€œIn time, and when everyone is able to, there will be more to say. But for now, we will take some time to grieve and process the loss of our brother, who we loved dearly.â€

The former boy banders said they would treasure their memories with Payne forever, and sent well wishes to his family, friends and their fans.

â€œWe love you Liam,â€ the bandmates signed off.

After the release of One Directionâ€™s joint statement, the bandmates slowly shared individual tributes to Payne on their social media accounts.

First to post was Tomlinson, who called Payne a role model and â€œ a positive, funny, and kind soul .â€



 A post shared by Louis Tomlinson (@louist91) 



â€œI first met Liam when he was 16 and I was 18, I was instantly amazed by his voice but more importantly as time went on I got a chance to see the kind brother Iâ€™d longed all my life for,â€ Tomlinson, 32, wrote. â€œLiam was an incredible song writer with a great sense of melody, we often spoke of getting back in the studio together to try and recreate the writing chemistry we had built up in the band.â€

Tomlinson called Payne â€œthe most vital part of One Directionâ€ and thanked him for shaping the band.

The singer then extended a personal message to Payne, â€œif youâ€™re listening.â€

Tomlinson said he is â€œbeyond luckyâ€ to have had Payne in his life but is â€œreally struggling with the idea of saying goodbye.â€

â€œReminiscing about all the thousands of amazing memories we had together is a luxury I thought Iâ€™d have with you for life,â€ he continued. â€œI would have loved to share the stage with you again but it wasnâ€™t to be.â€

Payne and Tomlinson have both admitted to having an occasionally tense relationship while they were members of One Direction. During an infamous interview on Logan Paulâ€™s podcast  Impaulsive , Payne in 2022 said he and Tomlinson despised one another to the point of physical arguments.

Though Payneâ€™s  interview was not well-received by One Direction fans,  Tomlinson later defended his bandmate  and said the podcast hosts were â€œdisrespectfulâ€ and took advantage of Payne, who had relapsed on his sobriety.

Tomlinson said he and Payne became closer friends after One Direction announced its hiatus in 2015.

Malik said heâ€™s been â€œtalking out loudâ€ to Payne since news of his death.

â€œI canâ€™t help but think selfishly that there are so many more conversations for us to have in our lives.â€ Malik, 31, wrote. â€œI never got to thank you for supporting me through some of the most difficult times in my life.â€

â€œWhen I was missing home as a 17 year old kid you would always be there with a positive outlook and reassuring smile and let me know that you were my friend and that I loved,â€ he remembered.



 A post shared by Zayn Malik (@zayn) 



Malik said he admired Payne, despite the fact that they â€œbutted headsâ€ often in their youth.

â€œI always secretly respected you for it,â€ Malik revealed of their arguments.

TheÂ singer said Payne was always the most â€œqualifiedâ€ musician and member of One Direction.

â€œI lost a brother when you left us and canâ€™t explain to you what Iâ€™d give to just give you a hug one last time and say goodbye to you properly and tell you that I loved and respected you dearly,â€ Malik concluded. â€œI will cherish all the memories I have with you in my heart forever, there is no words that justify or explain how I feel right now other than beyond devastated.â€

Malik suddenly left One Direction in 2015, and the band members continued for several months without him before announcing their hiatus.

He and Payne had a tumultuous relationship, which Payne spoke about â€” and later apologized for â€” on the  podcast.

Earlier this year,  Malik said he was grateful  to be a part of One Direction, but wished he had â€œenjoyedâ€ the experience more in his younger years.

â€œIâ€™m grateful that Iâ€™m able to be happier now,â€ Zayn said in an interview.

Styles shared a short statement about Payne to Instagram on Thursday and said he is â€œtruly devastatedâ€ by his bandmateâ€™s death.

â€œHis greatest joy was making other people happy, and it was an honour to be alongside him as he did it,â€ Styles, 30, wrote. â€œLiam lived wide open, with his heart on his sleeve, he had an energy for life that was infectious.â€



 A post shared by @harrystyles 



â€œHe was warm, supportive, and incredibly loving,â€ Styles said of Payne. â€œThe years we spent together will forever remain among the most cherished years of my life.â€

Styles said his â€œheart breaksâ€ for Payneâ€™s family members, his son and â€œall those around the world who knew him and loved him, as I did.â€

Styles has often spoken positively about his experience in One Direction and has credited the bandâ€™s development for his solo success.

In a 2022 interview with Zane Lowe, ahead of the release of his album Styles  reminisced about the One Direction years . He recalled the first time the bandmatesâ€™ photo together was published in a local newspaper, and how â€œhappyâ€ the then-teenagers were over the little success.

The last One Direction member to share a tribute to Payne was Horan, who was also the band member to meet Payne in person most recently.



 A post shared by Niall Horan (@niallhoran) 



Two weeks ahead of his death,  Payne attended Horanâ€™s stadium concert  in Argentina. Payne was seen dancing in a private box at the venue ahead of and during the show, then met with Horan afterward.

In a statement posted to social media Friday, Horan said he is â€œdevastated by the passing of my amazing friend, Liam.â€

Horan, 31, said he feels â€œfortunateâ€ to have seen Payne recently.

â€œI sadly didnâ€™t know that after saying goodbye and hugging him, I would be saying goodbye forever,â€ he wrote. â€œItâ€™s heartbreaking.â€

Horan said Payneâ€™s death â€œjust doesnâ€™t feel real.â€

â€œLiam had an energy for life and a passion for work that was infectious,â€ he continued. â€œHe was the brightest in every room and always made everyone feel happy and secure.â€

â€œAll the laughs we had over the years, sometimes about the simplest of things, keep coming to mind through the sadness,â€ Horan wrote. â€œWe got to live out our wildest dreams together and I will cherish every moment we had forever. The bond and friendship we had doesnâ€™t happen often in a lifetime.â€

Niall extended well wishes to Payneâ€™s family and thanked his bandmate for â€œeverything.â€

In 2023, Horan said One Direction â€œ feels like itâ€™s a separate life now .â€

Horan said he has â€œa good outlook on things, looking backâ€ and was grateful he â€œdidnâ€™t lose the plot along the way.â€

The members of One Direction met in 2010 on the U.K. singing competitionÂ when judges including Simon Cowell paired the then-teenage boys together in a group act.

Payne had already auditioned for two years prior but was eliminated early on. His successful second attempt at 16 years old positioned Payne as a leader among the five One Direction boys, known for their rowdy shenanigans.

One Directionâ€™s success was explosive. Until the band announced its hiatus in 2015, the membersâ€™ faces could commonly be found plastered on the bedroom walls of teenagers around the world.

Today, those fans are mourning the death of their  parasocial relationships  with Payne, alongside the One Direction members, who lost a beloved â€œbrother.â€

title: Indian diplomats in Canada are â€˜clearly on notice,â€™ Joly warns
description: The comments come just days after Canada expelled six Indian diplomats after the RCMP said it had evidence alleged Indian agents played a role in violent crimes on Canadian soil.
article:
Foreign Affairs Minister  Melanie Joly  says Indian diplomats in Canada are â€œon noticeâ€ after she was asked whether more expulsions could come amid the diplomatic row between  India  and  Canada. 

â€œTheyâ€™re clearly on notice,â€ Joly said in response to the question, speaking of other Indian diplomats following the expulsion of six earlier this week.

â€œClearly we wonâ€™t tolerate any diplomats that are in contravention of the Vienna Convention and clearly any diplomats from any country from around the world that would be putting the lives of Canadians at risk.â€

Jolyâ€™s comments come just days after both countries expelled each otherâ€™s diplomats on Monday, with Ottawa having done so â€œin relation to a targeted campaign against Canadian citizens by agents linked to the government of India.â€

Global News has learned agents working out of Indiaâ€™s high commission in Ottawa and consulates in Vancouver and Toronto were allegedly behind dozens of violent crimes across Canada that targeted opponents of the Narendra Modi government.

Although on paper they held diplomatic and consular positions, the Indian agents allegedly played key roles in a wave of shootings, killings, threats, arsons and extortions in Canada, according to senior sources familiar with the matter.

The victims were mostly supporters of theÂ  Khalistan Â movement, which seeks independence for Indiaâ€™s Sikh-majority Punjab region. But others were simply rivals of the government,Â the sources said.

The revelations came as Canadian law enforcement continues to probe the killing of Hardeep Singh Nijjar in Surrey, B.C., where the killers were allegedly linked to the Indian government.

Making the allegations public was an â€œextraordinary measureâ€ by the RCMP, Joly said on Friday, adding that the alleged actions by India were something not seen before in Canadian history.

â€œThat level of transnational repression cannot happen on Canadian soil,â€ she said. â€œWeâ€™ve seen it elsewhere in Europe, Russia has done that in Germany and the U.K., but we needed to stand firm on this issue.â€

title: Netflix stock sees new peak amid high hopes for â€˜Squid Gameâ€™ return
description: Streaming giant Netflix projected higher sign-ups for the last three months of the year when the hit South Korean drama 'Squid Game' returns.
article:
Netflix shares hit an all-time high on Friday, buoyed by investor optimism that its robust content lineup will help the streaming giant maintain upbeat subscriber growth even as the boost from its password-sharing crackdown wanes.

The company, widely seen as the winner of Hollywoodâ€™s streaming wars, saw its stock rise nearly 10% and was set to add more than $28 billion to its market value of about $295 billion, if gains hold.

It topped estimates for quarterly subscriber additions by more than 1 million and projected higher sign-ups sequentially for the last three months of the year when South Korean drama â€œSquid Gameâ€ returns.

The companyâ€™s profit and revenue also beat estimates, a positive sign for its efforts to shift investor focus away from subscriber growth amid what some analysts see as an inevitable slowdown in sign-ups after the success of its password-sharing curbs.

The 5.1 million users Netflix added in the third quarter were below the 8.76 million additions in the year-ago period.

â€œThe third quarter showed the slowdown in subscriber growth that weâ€™ve been expecting, but Netflix has other areas of opportunity to continue boosting its financial performance,â€ Morningstar analyst Matthew Dolgin said.

Part of the push includes price increases. After increasing fees in Japan, the Middle East and Africa as well as parts of Europe in recent weeks, Netflix is hiking prices in Italy and Spain, and some analysts expect a similar move in the U.S. next year.

â€œNetflix did not announce any price change, though (it) did hint that there is room to take price with stronger engagement,â€ Bernstein analysts said.

The ad-supported tier also showed signs of progress as it accounted for more than 50% of sign-ups in countries where it was available in the third quarter, though Netflix does not expect advertising to become a primary growth driver until 2026.

At least 20 analysts raised their price targets on the stock following results, bringing the median target to $760 from $706.38, according to data compiled by LSEG.

Netflixâ€™s shares were trading at 30.40 times 12-month forward profit estimates, compared with 18.50 for Walt Disney and Comcastâ€™s 9.65.

So far this year, Netflixâ€™s stock has risen about 41.2%, Disney has been up 6.9%, while Warner Bros Discovery has shed about 31%.

Netflix is betting on a strong line-up including the new â€œKnives Outâ€ movie, the latest season of â€œStranger Thingsâ€ and live events including two National Football League games on Christmas Day to draw subscribers.

â€œPeers in the legacy media space are losing money hand over fist, meaning Netflix can push its advantage in content creation while others canâ€™t stomach allocating more capital,â€ said Matt Britzman, senior equity analyst, Hargreaves Lansdown.

title: $5.5M for Jasper tourism recovery pledged by federal, provincial governments
description: Ottawa will spend $3 million on international advertising to attract visitors back to Jasper and Alberta is putting $2.5 million towards helping tourism businesses rebuild.
article:
The Alberta and federal governments are putting a combined $5.5 million toward attracting tourists to the Rocky Mountain town of  Jasper .

A July wildfire destroyed one-third of the town, including multiple hotels and 800 housing units.

Year-round tourism is Jasperâ€™s main economic driver as close to 2.5 million people visited the surrounding national park last year alone.

Soraya Martinez Ferrada, the federal tourism minister, said Friday that Ottawa will spend $3 million on tourism advertising across the globe to attract visitors back to Jasper.

â€œThis summerâ€™s wildfires across Western Canada were devastating to communities like Jasper that depend on tourism to drive their economy,â€ Ferrada said in a news release.

â€œI know that through concerted efforts with partners like Destination Canada and Travel Alberta, the municipality and region will bounce back, ready to once again host world-calibre events and welcome visitors from near and far.â€

Joseph Schow, Ferradaâ€™s Alberta counterpart, said Friday that his province is putting $2.5 million toward the same goal.

â€œThis funding will help Jasperâ€™s tourism businesses prepare to welcome visitors this fall and winter, ensuring they remain viable and ready for next summer,â€ he said in a news release.

Schow also said that some of the provincial funding will be earmarked for tourism businesses in Jasper to help rebuild and create new visitor experiences.

â€œTourism is the backbone of Jasperâ€™s economy, and for the town to rebuild, we need to see a strong return of tourism businesses, accommodation providers, services and experiences,â€ he said in the release.

The Insurance Bureau of Canada estimates the July fire caused at least $880 million in insured damages, which is the costliest event in national park history.

The $880 million total is thought to be the ninth highest natural disaster insurance payout total in Canadian history.

title: Boeing faces another review by U.S. FAA. What the agency is looking into
description: The FAA said its review will examine key areas of safety processes at Boeing to make sure that they â€œresult in timely, accurate safety-related information for FAA use.â€
article:
The Federal Aviation Administration said Friday it will open a three-month review of  Boeing â€™s compliance with safety regulations, continuing the agencyâ€™s closer oversight of the company since a panel blew off a jetliner during an Alaska Airlines flight in January.

The  FAA  said its review will examine key areas of safety processes at Boeing to make sure that they â€œresult in timely, accurate safety-related information for FAA use.â€

An FAA spokesperson said the review was not triggered by any particular event or concern but rather is part of the FAAâ€™s oversight of safety culture at the huge aircraft maker.

Boeing did not comment immediately on the new review.

FAA Administrator Mike Whitaker has ordered special audits of Boeing and other steps to examine the safety culture at Boeing since a panel called a door plug blew off a 737 Max during the Alaska Airlines flight.

However, the inspector general of the Transportation Department, FAAâ€™s parent agency, said last week that weaknesses in FAA oversight are limiting its ability to find and fix problems at Boeing.

The auditor said FAA has failed to ensure that Boeing and its suppliers make parts that meet engineering and design requirements and to investigate claims that Boeing puts improper pressure on employees who are authorized to conduct safety inspections. The FAA has closed only 14 of 34 reports of undue pressure, with the others remaining open for more than a year on average, according to the report.

Last month, the National Transportation Safety Board issued an â€œurgentâ€ recommendation to FAA about a problem that surfaced in February with rudders that pilots use to steer certain Boeing 737s after landing. Two weeks later, the FAA later issued a safety alert to airlines about the matter.

title: â€˜Vast majorityâ€™ of Liberal caucus supports Trudeau: Freeland
description: Her comments come ahead of what promises to be a tense meeting of the Liberal caucus in Ottawa next week as a growing number of MPs try to convince Justin Trudeau to step down.
article:
Deputy Prime Minister  Chrystia Freeland  says she is â€œabsolutely confidentâ€ the majority of  Liberal  MPs still support Prime Minister  Justin Trudeau  as leader.

Her comments at a press conference in Winnipeg Friday came ahead of what promises to be a tense meeting of the Liberal caucus in Ottawa next week as a growing number of MPs try to convince Trudeau to step down.

Several media reports have uncovered efforts by some Liberal MPs to confront the prime minister at the next caucus meeting on Oct. 23, following more than a year of dismal polling and the growing fear their party will be decimated in the next election.

There is no mechanism for caucus to force the prime minister to step down as leader, and he has so far not wavered in his plans to stay on.

Â 

â€

â€œIn any caucus, there is going to be a wide range of views. I am absolutely confident that the vast majority of members of our caucus support the prime minister.â€

Details about the exact strategy and breadth of the attempt to push Trudeau to resign remains unclear, though some MPs who have spoken to The Canadian Press on background say the number of MPs involved is significant.

Freeland expressed her own full support for Trudeau, and Foreign Affairs Minister MÃ©lanie Joly said at a separate press conference Friday that he can count on her loyalty as well.

Joly encouraged MPs to talk to the prime minister himself at the caucus meeting next Wednesday.

â€œHe will be the one deciding,â€ she said.

A fall election has looked increasingly more likely as opposition parties muse about bringing down the government in a confidence vote, and the Conservatives have locked Parliament into a weeksâ€™ long debate over a matter of privilege in the House.

Trudeau could avert both problems by taking the controversial step of proroguing Parliament, which some political watchers have mused would allow time for a Liberal leadership race if he were to step down.

In the meantime, the prime minister also plans to shuffle his cabinet to replace four cabinet ministers who donâ€™t plan to run again in the next election.

One of those ministers, Northern Affairs Minister Dan Vandal, said Friday heâ€™s not leaving because of Trudeau or the Liberalsâ€™ re-election prospects.

â€œIt does not mean that Iâ€™ve lost confidence in our party or the prime minister,â€ said Vandal, who spoke at the same press conference as Freeland.

â€œIn fact, Iâ€™m very confident that the polls are going to tighten up as time goes on, and I think it would be foolish to vote against our party.â€

title: Can your standing desk raise health risks? A new study says you can go too far
description: A new study says that using a standing desk at work promotes health, but it can be too much of a good thing. The trick is finding a balance between time spent sitting and standing.
article:
The term â€œsitting is the new smokingâ€ has been cautioning office-workers against being sedentary in recent years, but a new study suggests that some may be swinging too far in the other direction.

Standing desks have risen in popularity, with the global market  valued  at USD $7.75 billion, but new research warns against relying too much on them.

The study, led by the University of Sydney and published in the International Journal of Epidemiology, studied 83,â€Š013 adults in the United Kingdom to assess daily time spent sitting and standing. The study found that being on your feet for more than two hours a day can cause problems such as varicose veins, but does little to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease that comes with prolonged sitting.

Dr. Patricia Doyle-Baker, from the faculty of kinesiology at the University of Calgary, said, â€œAnybody who stands for a long period of time in a very still position is going to have some issues associated with either muscular-skeletal system or theyâ€™ll have blood pooling in their legs and in their feet.â€

However, Doyle-Baker said that what the study points out is not that standing desks are inherently bad for your health, but that holding any position for prolonged periods of time can be bad â€” whether itâ€™s sitting or standing.

Scott Lear, professor of health sciences at Simon Fraser University, said, â€œItâ€™s not just sitting. Itâ€™s sedentary behaviour that is problematic â€” not moving.â€

He said, â€œItâ€™s a different posture than sitting. But as this study showed, it comes also with its own risks for heart disease and other things like varicose veins.â€

Doyle-Baker said, â€œThis article is not saying donâ€™t necessarily not stand at your desk, but think about the prolonged amount of time standing at your desk.â€

Lear said standing users should be wary of blood pooling in their feet or legs.

â€œIf it pools and itâ€™s not moving, some of the blood cells can cleave together and create these little clots,â€ he said. â€œWhat happens when the blood moves up from our feet and our lower legs? It goes to our heart and passes through the inner chambers of the heart and then goes to our lungs. And so that little clot will keep going merrily along until it gets to a blood vessel thatâ€™s too narrow.â€

This, he said, can cause a pulmonary embolism for some people.

So should you throw your standing desk away? Not quite. Sitting for prolonged periods is still quite bad for you.

â€œSitting for extended, continuous periods can increase your chances for diabetes, heart disease, some cancers and a whole bunch of other diseases,â€ Lear said.

So if, sitting and standing can both cause health issues, what solution is there for the health conscious office worker? The answer, some experts say, may lie in height-adjustable sit-and-stand desks.

A 2020 paper published by the Centre of Research Expertise for the Prevention of Musculoskeletal Disorders (CRE-MSD) at the University of Waterloo said sit-stand workstations can help alleviate pain issues for some users. People suffering from conditions such as herniated disks in their spines could benefit from sit-stand desks.

â€œSit-Stand workstations can be effective for some individuals in relieving musculoskeletal discomfort, in particular low back pain,â€ the paper said.

The paper recommends office users employ a 1:1 ratio, which means in an eight-hour work day, you should ideally be sitting for four hours and standing for four hours. But it depends on how you split your time.

Jack Callaghan, one of the co-authors of the University of Waterloo paper, said, â€œOur gold standard, if people can do it, is you shouldnâ€™t sit longer than 30 minutes without doing something else. And you should never stand longer than 15 minutes continuously.â€

Doyle-Baker said some people could benefit from something called the â€œ20-eight-two ruleâ€.

â€œYou sit for 20 minutes, you stand for eight minutes and you move for two minutes,â€ she said.

If you donâ€™t have a standing desk or a height-adjustable standing desk but donâ€™t want to spend the money, Lear said there are things you could incorporate in your day to make sure your body is in movement every 20 to 30 minutes.

â€œIf youâ€™re working at home, it could be going upstairs, doing the laundry or just walking around,â€ he said.

If youâ€™re at the office, small things like taking regular breaks to the coffee machine or water cooler could help.

â€œI like to encourage people setting their phone alarm or something, where after half an hour it goes off. You can have the watches that will buzz if youâ€™re not moving around,â€ he said. â€œOur joints like movement and our joints get lubricated when they move.â€

Callaghan said the most sedentary hours often come not during work, but after work.

â€œ(Sometimes) itâ€™s not what youâ€™re doing at work. Itâ€™s what youâ€™re doing outside work, whether youâ€™re spending an hour in the car, spending four hours on the couch,â€ he said.

Callaghan recommended ditching your car for active transportation, such as public transit or bicycles, every once in a while, if possible.

For your home office, Doyle-Baker said a sit-stand desk might be a good idea.

â€œI think anyone can benefit from a sit-to-stand situation,â€ she said. â€œI think standing desks are here to stay.â€

title: Ruby Frankeâ€™s daughter warns about family vlogging: â€˜It ruined my innocenceâ€™
description: Shari Franke said long before her mother was arrested for child abuse, she felt extreme and damaging pressure to perform for the camera.
article:
Shari Franke, the oldest daughter of  convicted child abuser  and â€œmommy vloggerâ€  Ruby Franke , spoke out about being a â€œvictim of family vloggingâ€ and the â€œdangersâ€ of parents who monetize their children on social media.

She spoke to lawmakers on Utahâ€™s Business and Labor Interim Committee in Salt Lake City on Wednesday, advocating for more protections for child  influencers  and describing what went on behind the camera as a child influencer herself.

â€œMy mother, Ruby Franke, is the prominent family vlogger arrested last year for child abuse. I donâ€™t come today as the daughter of a felon, nor a victim of an abnormally abusive mother,â€ she said in her opening remarks, which she shared on Instagram.



 A post shared by Shari Franke (@sharilfranke) 



â€œI come today as a victim of family vlogging. My goal today is not to present any idea of a solution to this problem, but to shed light on the ethical and monetary issues that come from being a child influencer.â€

 Ruby Franke was arrested  in August of last year, after her 12-year-old son escaped through the window of business partner Jodi Hildebrandtâ€™s house and sought help from a neighbour, begging for food and water. When emergency responders found him, he was  injured, starved and had duct tape on his wrists and ankles  covering up wounds.

Frankeâ€™s 10-year-old daughter was also found in a similar condition when police searched the home.

In February, Franke was handed  four one-to-15-year-long prison sentence s by a Utah district court. Hildebrandt received the exact same sentence.

On Wednesday, Shari Franke spoke from personal experience to share the negative impact family vlogging has had on her life. She began appearing in her motherâ€™s videos, alongside her five other siblings, in 2015.

â€œIt is more than just filming your family life and putting it online,â€ she said. â€œIt is a full-time job with employees, business credit cards, managers and marketing strategies.â€

She noted that family vlogging is different from a normal, family-run business, as â€œall the children are employees,â€ and almost always the â€œstarsâ€ of their parentsâ€™ social media content.

â€œThere is no such thing as a moral or ethical family vlogger,â€ she said, adding that while she was often paid for her work, the money was usually in the form of a bribe.

â€œâ€¦Going on vacation was expected to be payment enough because most kids donâ€™t get to go on regular and expensive trips,â€ she continued, adding that â€œthe childâ€™s labour is actually what paid for the vacation or trip.â€

She then went on to share some of her most traumatic experiences as a child influencer.

â€œSome of our most popular videos were when my eyebrow was accidentally waxed off, and the whole world saw a crying teenager who just wanted to mourn in private,â€ she said.

â€œOr the time I was violently ill, and got the leading role in the video for that day. My friends became scarce, because dates would be filmed and none of my friends wanted to be on camera.â€

She added, â€œIf I could go back and do it all again, Iâ€™d rather have an empty bank account now and not have my childhood plastered all over the internet. No amount of money I received has made what Iâ€™ve experienced worth it.â€



 A post shared by Shari Franke (@sharilfranke) 



Only two U.S. states have laws around financial protections for teens and children who are featured on social media. Last year, Illinois enacted legislation that â€œcreates a private right of action for child influencers against their parents that featured them in videos and  did not properly compensate them ,â€ according to Gov. J.B. Pritzkerâ€™s website.

More recently, California Gov. Gavin Newsom  passed legislation  that mandates parents and guardians set aside in trust accounts a percentage of earnings earned by minors who are â€œfeatured in monetized online content.â€

Shari Franke said Wednesday that her motherâ€™s crimes aside, what she experienced as a child influencer is â€œnot unique.â€

â€œFamily vlogging ruined my innocence long before Ruby committed a crime. I promise you that my experiences are not unique, and are happening to child influencers all over Utah and the country. Letâ€™s tackle this issue before it becomes a bigger crisis than it already is.â€

She also announced her upcoming memoir, that promises to â€œcover the painful journey and experiences of growing up under intense public scrutiny.â€



 A post shared by Shari Franke (@sharilfranke)

title: Cuba plunged into darkness after national power grid fails
description: The crisis marks a new low on an island where life has become increasingly unbearable, with residents already suffering from shortages of food, fuel, water and medicine.
article:
Cuba Â plunged into a countrywide  blackout  on Friday after one of the islandâ€™s major power plants failed and caused the national electrical grid to shut down, its energy ministry said.

The Communist-run government had already closed schools and non-essential industry and sent most state workers home in a last-ditch effort to keep the lights on duringÂ severe power shortages.

But shortly before midday, the Antonio Guiteras power plant, the countryâ€™s largest and most efficient, went offline, prompting a total grid failure and leaving approximately 10 million people without power.

Officials did not say what had caused the plant to fail.

â€œThere will be no rest until (power) is restored,â€Â Cuban President Miguel Diaz-Canel said on X.

The blackout marks a new low point on an island where life has become increasingly unbearable, with residents already suffering fromÂ shortages of food, fuel, water and medicine.

The electricity shortages had already prompted officials to cancel all non-vital government services on Friday. Schools, including universities, were shuttered through Sunday. Recreational and cultural activities, including night clubs, were also ordered closed.

Officials said in mid-afternoon they had begun taking steps to restore power but that the process would take time.

Virtually all commerce in the capital Havana ground to a halt on Friday. Many residents sat sweating on doorsteps. Tourists hunkered down in frustration.

â€œWe went to a restaurant and they had no food because there was no power, now we are also without internet,â€ said Brazilian tourist Carlos Roberto Julio, who had recently arrived in Havana. â€œIn two days, we have already had several problems.â€

Prime Minister Manuel Marrero late on Thursday blamed worsening blackouts during the past several weeks on a perfect storm well-known to mostÂ Cubans â€“ deteriorating infrastructure, fuel shortages and rising demand.

â€œThe fuel shortage is the biggest factor,â€ Marrero said in a televised message that was garbled by technical difficulties and delayed several hours.

â€œThe situation has worsened in recent days,â€ the prime minister said. â€œWe must be fully transparent â€¦ we have been halting economic activities to ensure energy for the population.â€

Strong winds that began with Hurricane Milton last week has crippled the islandâ€™s ability to deliver scarce fuel from boats offshore to its power plants, officials said.

Cubaâ€™s government also blames the U.S. trade embargo, as well as new sanctions under former PresidentÂ Donald Trump, for difficulties in acquiring fuel and spare parts to operate its oil-fired plants.

â€œThe complex scenario is caused primarily by the intensification of the economic war and financial and energy persecution of the United States,â€ Diaz-Canel said on X on Thursday.

â€œThe United States is not to blame for todayâ€™s blackout on the island, or the overall energy situation inÂ Cuba,â€ a spokesperson for the White House National Security Council said.

While demand for electricity has grown alongsideÂ Cubaâ€™s private sector, fuel supply has evaporated.

Cubaâ€™s largest oil supplier, Venezuela, has reduced shipments to the island to an average of 32,600 barrels per day in the first nine months of the year, about half of the 60,000 bpd sent in the same period of 2023, according to vessel-monitoring data and internal shipping documents from Venezuelaâ€™s state company PDVSA.

PDVSA, whose refining infrastructure is also ailing, has this year tried to avoid a new wave of fuel scarcity at home, leaving smaller volumes available for export to allied countries likeÂ Cuba.

Russia and Mexico, which in the past have sent fuel toÂ Cuba, have also greatly reduced shipments to the island.

The shortfalls have leftÂ CubaÂ to fend for itself on the far costlier spot market at a time when its government is near-bankrupt.

Electricity officials said they nonetheless expect power generation to improve in the coming days as the weather allows fuel from prior deliveries to be distributed around the Caribbeanâ€™s largest island.

title: Canada to send Ukraine more ammunition, arms in $65M military aid package
description: Defence Minister Bill Blair made the announcement at a NATO defence ministers' meeting in Brussels where Ukraine's ongoing war with Russia was a key topic.
article:
Canada announced the details of a $64.8 million military aid package toÂ  Ukraine Â Friday as National Defence Minister  Bill Blair  attended a NATO defence ministers meeting in Brussels.

Ukraineâ€™s ongoing war with  Russia  was a key topic at the meeting, and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addressed the ministers during the meeting.

NATO Secretary-General Mark Rutte, chairing his first NATO defence ministersâ€™ meeting since taking the role earlier in October, said the allianceâ€™s members are on track to deliver almost $60 billion in security assistance toÂ Ukraine.

â€œThe war inÂ UkraineÂ has shown that instability in Europe can have far-reaching consequences across the world, and that countries thousands of miles away â€” as far away as Iran, China and even North Korea â€” can become security spoilers in our own backyard,â€ Rutte said, according to a statement published by NATO.

Canada has committed more than $19.5 billion in support toÂ UkraineÂ since Russiaâ€™s invasion in February 2022. That includes the $500 million promised by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at the NATO summit in July.

The money Blair announced Friday comes out of that July commitment, of which more than $50 million will help buy arms, ammunition and military drones as well as uniforms and personal protective equipment for Ukrainian soldiers.

The remaining funding is to support military training for those soldiers and to strengthen Ukrainian cyber forces.

In a statement on X posted after the meeting, Zelenskyy expressed the importance of his alliesâ€™ collective support ofÂ UkraineÂ during the Russian invasion.

â€œOnly through joint pressure on Russia, using all available means and tools, can we achieve our goal of real and just peace as quickly as possible,â€ Zelenskyy said.

U.S. President Joe Biden encouraged Western allies to continue supportingÂ UkraineÂ in a meeting with European leaders Friday in Germany.

â€œAsÂ UkraineÂ faces a tough winter, we must â€” we must â€” sustain our resolve, our effort and our support,â€ Biden said.

title: Canadian businesses can request relief from Chinese EV, metals tariffs
description: The Department of Finance saidÂ in a statement that temporary reliefÂ from tariffs would be granted under specific and exceptional circumstances.
article:
Canadian firms can request a temporary remission ofÂ tariffs on the  imports of Chinese electric vehicles , steel and aluminum products, the finance ministry said on Friday.

The ministry saidÂ in a statement that reliefÂ would be granted under specific and exceptional circumstances. The measure is designed to help firms adjust their supply chains to cope with the newÂ tariffs, it saidÂ in a statement.

Canada announced the measures in late August, citing Chinaâ€™s intentional, state-directed policy of over-capacity. A 100% surtax on EVs was imposed on Oct. 1 while a 25% surtax on steel and aluminum products comes into effect on Oct. 22.

â€œTo ensure that Canadian industry has sufficient time to adjust supply chains, remission will provide relief â€¦ under specific and exceptional circumstances,â€ the ministry said.

â€œThe federal government will consider the appropriate duration of remission, with intent to provide it on a transitional basis only in most cases,â€ according to the ministry.

Remission would be considered in the following cases:

*Situations where goods used as inputs, or substitutes for those goods, cannot be sourced either domestically or reasonably from non-Chinese sources.

*Where there are contractual requirements, existing prior to Aug. 26, 2024, requiring businesses to purchase Chinese inputs into their products or projects for a specified period of time.

*Other exceptional circumstances, on a case-by-case basis, that could have significant adverse impacts on the economy.

Remission will not be granted for goods intended for resale in the same condition to the United States.
